3.heading: Brave Knight of the Sword.
3.title: "Guru Tegh Bahadur : the Gentle Sikh Warrior"
3.author: script, Ramkrishna Sudhakar ; illustrations, Ranjana ; editor, Anant Pai
3.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 694 (1976, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "The 13-year-old fought as valiantly as a lion and his proud father dubbed him Tegh Bahadur, or Brave Knight of the Sword. But this lad also loved the arts, had studied the sciences, and enjoyed spending time in prayer and meditation. Moreover, he was truly selfless, and it was this quality that made him such a fitting leader of men, even in his death."

4.heading: "Brave Little Brave" (Tommy Hawk) 2 p. in Master Comics, no.
4.author: [No author]
notes: Data from Bob Klein, Lou Mougin, and Jim Vadeboncoeur via The Grand Comics Database Project.

5.title: "The Brave Little Tailor"
5.author: adapted from the cartoon by Merrill de Maris ; penciled by Floyd Gottfredson and Manuel Gonzales ; inked by Ted Thwaites
5.appears_in: 28 p. in Walt Disney's Mickey Mouse, no. 246 (Apr. 1989) ; reprinted from newspaper strips, Aug. 28 to Nov. 27, 1938. I. [Each creator] II. Mickey Mouse. k. Tailors. Call no.: PN6728.1.D4M5no.246

6.heading: The Brave Little Tailor.
6.title: Mickey Mouse Surprise Party : Mickey and his friends celebrate highlights of his famous career.
6.author: [No author]

contents.title: "The Timber Treasure Trail" (18 p.) 1. Funny animal comics. I. [Each story title] II. Series. III. Western Publishing Company. Call no.: PN6728.4.G56W36no.47

7.heading: Brave Little Tailor.
7.title: Walt Disney's The Brave Little Tailor.
7.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: When Mickey the tailor kills seven flies, everyone thinks they were seven giants and he inadvertently becomes the king's giant-killer. I. Mickey Mouse. II. Brave Little Tailor. III. Series. Call no.: PN1997.5.B7W3 1974

9.title: "A Brave Mad World"
9.author: by Michael Lerner
9.appears_in: p. 26-27, 34-35, 59-61 in Baby Boomer Collectibles, v. 1, no. 3 (Dec. 1993)
notes: Collectors and collecting. 2. Comic art paraphernalia
Collectors and collecting. I. Lerner, Michael. II. Baby Boomer Collectibles. Call no.: N7429.5.B3v.1no.3

10.title: "The Brave Messenger"
10.author: Bill Walsh
10.appears_in: p. 10-15 in Treasure Chest of Fun & Fact, v. 23, no. 2 (Sept. 21, 1967).
notes: In the War of 1812, a Canadian girl causes the defeat of an invading American army.

notes: Data from Pete Coogan. 1. Brave New Words. Call no.: PN6700.C62no.139

14.title: "Brave New Whirl : A Survey of IconoGraphix Comix"
14.author: a review by Rich Kreiner
14.appears_in: p. 109-112 in The Comics Journal, no. 157 (Mar. 1993)

15.heading: Brave New Words.
15.title: The Contaminated Zone
15.author: by Matt Howarth.
notes: "Starring Those annoying Post Bros. and Savage Henry, featuring the origin of Caroline."

16.heading: Brave New Words.
16.title: Fix
16.author: by Matt Howarth.
notes: "Fix and Fixed were originally published as minicomics in 1977 and 1983, respectively, and are collected here for the first time."

18.title: Oz Squad.

19.title: Polis.
19.author: [No author]
notes: "Written by Ed Fuqua ; illustrated by Al Bigley ; cover by Kent Bingham ; lettered by Sam Newcome and Willie Schubert ; edited by E. Jordan Bojar ; created by Ed Fuqua with Kent Bingham."

21.heading: Brave New Words.
21.title: Wartime and Wedding Bells
21.author: by Donna Barr.
notes: Originally appeared as Stinz #1-5, and in Critters #27. 1. Fantasy comics. 2. War comics. I. Barr, Donna. II. Critters, no. 27. III. Series. IV. Brave New Words. k. Wedding Bells. Call no.: PN6727.B355W3 1992

notes: Letter on Scott McCloud and the future of comics. 1. McCloud, Scott. I. Juricich, Chris. Call no.: PN6700.C62no.189

notes: Data from Pete Coogan. 1. Brave New Words. I. Luciano, Dale. Call no.: PN6700.C62no.57

26.title: Dahl's Brave New World : cartoons

notes: "An Atlantic Monthly Press Book." I. Dahl, Francis Wellington, 1907- II. Morton, Charles W., 1899- III. Brave New World. IV. Little, Brown. V. An Atlantic Monthly Press Book. Call no.: NC1429.D15

28.title: "Brave Nouveau Worlds : Two New Books Showcase the Sublime Art of Michael Kaluta"
28.author: by Kenneth Smith
28.appears_in: p. 63-66 in The Comics Journal Special Edition, v. 3 (Winter 2003).
notes: Reviews: Wings of Twilight, the Art of Michael Kaluta ; and Echoes, the Drawings of Michael William Kaluta.

30.title: The Brave One.
30.author: [No author]
notes: Comic books, strips, etc. I. Series: Four Color ; no. 773. Call no.: PN6728.2.D4B72 1957

31.heading: "The Brave Pig."
31.title: "Jataka Tales : Stories of Courage"
31.author: script, Margie Sastry ; illustrations ; Chandrakant Rane
31.appears_in: 28 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 615 (1990, 1998 printing).

32.title: "The Brave Quail" p. 12-19 in Elephant Stories : Jataka Tales of Nobility
32.author: [No author]

36.title: "The Brave Tank"
36.author: Russ Heath, art
36.appears_in: 6 p. in Our Army at War, no. 242 (Feb. 1972) ; reprinted from G.I. Combat, no. 44 (Jan. 1957).

37.heading: Brave Viking Warriors.
37.title: "So Long, Guys!"
37.author: Chris Browne.
notes: Summary: Hagar raises his mug to the brave Viking warriors who battle tomorrow against overwhelming odds, and Lucky Eddie adds his perspective.

38.heading: Braveheart.
38.title: The Blank in the Comics strip collection includes a file of one or more daily comic strips related to this keyword or topic. Call no.: PN6726 f.B55
38.author: [No author]

39.heading: Braveheart.
39.title: The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Cartoon Animals
39.author: Jeff Rovin

40.heading: Bravehearts.
40.title: "Ajatashatru : a Son's Story of Sorrow and Success"
40.author: script, Appaswami ; editor, Anant Pai
40.appears_in: p. 1-27 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 660 (1988, 2010 printing).
notes: Begins: "Prasenajit, the king of Kosala, called a meeting of his council of ministers. 'Bimisara, the king of Magadha, is dead.'"

Summary from back cover: "Ajatashatru is ridden with guilt. What does a king do when, in a moment of misguided ambition, he orders the death of his own father? Ajatashatru wages war on his neighbors with brilliant new machines, expands his realm to make it a powerful empire and founds the new capital city of Pataliputra (modern Patna). But try as he might, he cannot shed his feelings of remorse and sorrow, until Gautama Buddha shows him the way."

41.heading: Bravehearts.
41.title: "Akbar : a Visionary Monarch"
41.author: script, Toni Patel ; illustrations, Souren Roy ; editor, Anant Pai
41.appears_in: p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 603 (1979, 2010 printing).
notes: Begins: "In the year 1556, Akbar was just thirteen years old, yet his military training had already begun. His father, Humayun, the Mughal emperor, had sent him with his faithful general, Bairam Kahn, to fight in Punjab against their enemy Sikandar Shah."

Summary from back cover: "He was a child, who only wanted to ride elephants and hunt tigers. Crowned emperor of Hindustan at the age of 13, he was mature enough to choose his friends carefully. Enemies and dangerous courtiers, on the other hand, were dispatched mercilessly. For his courage and generosity, his love of the arts and universal justice, history gives Jalaluddin Muhammad Akbar an enduring label: Akbar the Great."

42.heading: Bravehearts.
42.title: "Ashoka : the Warrior Who Spoke of Peace"
42.author: script, Meena Talim ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
42.appears_in: 32 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 536 (1973, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "A power-hungry warrior and a peace-loving wife, could they ever tread together on the path of non-violence? Ashoka waged war after ruthless war, yet by the time his children grew up, he proudly saw them off as Buddhist missionaries. Read about the charmed life of this famous king of Magadha, who not only built a prosperous kingdom but spread the message of universal love."

43.heading: Bravehearts.
43.title: "Bagha Jatin : the 'Tiger' Revolutionary"
43.author: script, Shanta Patil and Subba Rao ; illustrations, Souren Roy ; editor, Anant Pai
43.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 724 (1985, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "When a tiger attacked Jatin Mukherji, his friends felt sorry for the tiger! The animal was killed and Jatin spent only a short time in hospital recuperating from his wounds. The young man went on to display grit and determination to combat the worst of British colonialism in Bengal. He inspired his countrymen, who were in awe of their British masters, to stand tall and proud."

44.heading: Bravehearts.
44.title: "Baji Rao I : the Warrior Peshwa"
44.author: script, B
44.appears_in: R. Bhagawat ; illustrations, V.B. Halbe ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 729 (1974, 2010 printing).
notes: Begins: "In 1718, Balaji Vishwanath, the peshwa or prime minister of the Marathas, was a power to reckon with. His young son Baji Rao was imbued with the martial spirit."

Summary from back cover: "Baji Rao, the warrior Peswa (Maratha Prime Minister), fought 36 battles leading his men to victory time after time. He made the Marathas a formidable power in the country, even as the once powerful Afghan Mughals started showing signs of decline."

45.heading: Bravehearts.
45.title: "Baladitya and Yashodharma : Bane of the Hunas"
45.author: script, Kamlesh Pandey ; illustrations, Dilip Kadam ; editor, Anant Pai
45.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 717 (1980, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "In the 5th century AD the Hunas of Gandhara or modern Afghanistan had their eyes trained on the rich kingdoms of India. Toramana, the leader of the Hunas, and after him his son, Mihirakula, were determined to conquer the prosperous kingdom of Magadha. But they had a formidable rival in its ruler, Narasimha Gupta Baladitya. And when the Hunas turned their eyes of Malwa it was King Yashodharma who fought them off."

46.heading: Bravehearts.
46.title: "Banda Bahadur : a Valiant Sikh Warrior"
46.author: script, S
46.appears_in: Khushwant Singh ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 734 (1973, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Inspired by Guru Gobind Singh, Banda Bahadur led the Sikh rebellion against the Mughal Empire. For eight years, he ravaged the whole of North India. The havoc he created in the Indo-Gangetic plain was of such magnitude that the Mughals could never restore their administration. Invasions by the Persian tyrant Nadir Shah and the Afghan Ahmed Shah Abdali hastened the decline of the once mighty empire which helped the Sikhs to emerge as the rulers of Punjab. Banda Bahadur thus paved the way for the foundation of the Sikh Kingdom."

47.heading: Bravehearts.
47.title: "Bappa Rawal : a Great Rajput Hero"
47.author: script, Rajendra Sanjay ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
47.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 705 (1975, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "He was known as a hardworking, honest young cowherd, but Bappa Rawal's bearing and talents were that of a well-bred prince. And one day he was to unite the divided Rajput clans to regain their lost glory. This gallant 8th century ruler of Chittor lived to be a hundred years old, enjoying his last years in the tranquility of the remote Himalayas."

48.heading: Bravehearts.
48.title: "Bhagat Singh : the Cheerful Young Martyr"
48.author: script, Rajinder Singh and Subba Rao ; illustrations, Dilip Kadam ; editor, Anant Pai
48.appears_in: p. 1-30 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 608 (1981, 2009 printing).
notes: Begins: "September 27, 1907: In the village of Banga, near Lahore, the birth of a baby brought joy to the otherwise gloomy household of Sardar Kishan Singh."

Summary from back cover: "Bhagat Singh sang gustily as he walked to the gallows. Backed by a courageous family, this twenty three year old firebrand was wedded to death. A free India was his heaven, and the martyrs of the freedom struggle were his gods. Using disguise and guile, persuasion and force, his life was a roller-coaster ride through an unjust system. But eventually, he awakened India and the world to the idea of liberty, and brought the mighty British Raj to its knees."

49.heading: Bravehearts.
49.title: "Bimbisara : Model King of Magadha"
49.author: script, H
49.appears_in: Atmaram ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-30 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 688 (1983, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Dutiful son, doting father, capable general, wise ruler: Bimbisara had earned the right to grow old in peace; but his son had other plans for him. Through his darkest hours Bimbisara was sustained by the gentle teachings of his royal-born friend Gautama Buddha, who had renounced his own kingdom of Magadha around present-day Bihar. We get a glimpse of the life and times of this great king, who lived nearly 2500 years ago, in the Buddhist and Jain literature of the period."

50.heading: Bravehearts.
50.title: "Chand Bibi : the Fearless Queen"
50.author: script, Toni Patel ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
50.appears_in: p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 685 (1974, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "The Mughals thought that Ahmednagar would be easy to take as the heir was only a child and his regent, a woman. However, Akbar's mighty army was surprised when they ran into a determined band of defenders. In the battle for Ahmednagar, one woman stood between the Mughals and the fort that they sought to win: Chand Bibi. Such was the spirt of Chand Bibi that the mighty Mughals had to sue for peace."

51.heading: Bravehearts.
51.title: "Chandra Shekhar Azad : Freedom Was His Mission"
51.author: script, Shail Tiwari ; illustrations, H
51.appears_in: S. Chavan ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 686 (1977, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Chandra Shekhar was only a little boy when he ran away to Bombay in search of adventure. Little did he know how much he would get involved in the country's freedom struggle. Those were the days when the non-cooperation movement had gathered immense momentum and it was in Varanasi that Chandra Shekhar first confronted British authority. After that there was no looking back. Assuming the surname 'Azad' he and his band of revolutionaries did much to awaken in the Indian people the desire for freedom. Martyred at the age of 25, Chandra Shekhar Azad has left an indelible mark on the history of Indian independence."

52.heading: Bravehearts.
52.title: "Chandragupta Maurya : the Determined Prince"
52.author: script, Subba Rao ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
52.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 634 (1978, 2009 printing).
notes: "Chandragupta Maurya defeated the Nandas and established himself on the throne of Magadha in 321 B.C. It was a journey fraught with dangerous challenges but his chance meeting with the wily Chanakya changed his destiny forever. The clever Brahmin showed him how by the sheer brilliance of his wit and wile he could help the young Mauryan prince to rise from being an unknown warrior to one of the greatest emperors of India."

53.heading: Bravehearts.
53.title: "Durgadas : the Loyal Courtier"
53.author: script, Ramesh Sinha ; illustrations, V
53.appears_in: B. Halbe ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 739 (1974, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "The struggle for power between the Rajputs and Mughals during the medieval period in Indian history is replete with stories of courage on both sides. One such tale that is oft repeated is that of Durgadas, the son of the prime minister of King Jaswant Singh of Jodhpur. He vowed to liberate Jodhpur from the Mughal overlords and crown Jaswant Singh's son Ajeet Singh as king. Loyal Durgadas plotted and planned to achieve this goal all his life. With a combination of valour and wile he managed to succeed in his mission after Aurangzeb's death in 1707."

54.heading: Bravehearts.
54.title: "Ellora Caves : the Glory of the Rashtrakootas"
54.author: script, H
54.appears_in: Atmaram ; illustrations, Ramanand Bhagat ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-29 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 731 (1988, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "The Rashtrakootas who ruled in Decan for two and a half centuries (752 to 982 AD) respected all faiths of their time. This is reflected in Ellora where we find rock-cut cave-temples representing the Vaishnava, Shaiva, Jaina and Buddhist faiths. This Amar Chitra Katha tells the story of the Rashtrakoota heroes who have left us a lasting legacy, the Ellora Caves.
Splash title: "The Glory of the Rashtrakootas."

55.heading: Bravehearts.
55.title: "Harsha : a Gallant King of Kanauj"
55.author: script, Yagya Sharma, Anand Prakash Singh ; illustrations, Madhu Powle ; editor, Anant Pai
55.appears_in: 32 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 627 (1972, 2010 printing).
notes: "Starting off as the ruler of tiny Thaneshwar, Harsha (7th century AD) rose to become the powerful monarch of the kingdom of Kanauj. He avenged the wicked assassination of his elder brother and the cowardly abduction of his sister. His biographer Bona Bhatta and the Chinese traveler Hiuen Tsang were unanimous in their praise of this learned king, whose fame did much to create a glowing image of India in lands far away."

56.heading: Bravehearts.
56.title: "The Historic City of Delhi : a Tale of Power and Passion"
56.author: script, Luis M
56.appears_in: Fernandes ; illustrations, Arvind Mandrekar ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 696 (1983, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Down its 1000-year-old recorded history, Delhi was razed and built several times. The city played host to many rulers like the Chauhans, the Slave kings, the Khiljis, the Tughlugs, the Mughals and the British. It suffered the brutalities of numerous invaders. Each ruler and each invader left his own special mark on the psyche of this great city. The historic city of Delhi presents a palette of colourful influences that truly reflects the composite culture of India."

57.heading: Bravehearts.
57.title: "Jahangir : the Gentle Mughal"
57.author: script, Kamala Chandrakant ; illustrations, Souren Roy ; editor, Anant Pai
57.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 658 (1980, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Jahangir was born to a life tailor-made for happiness. In addition to wealth and fame, he held a special place in his father's heart. Growing up into a sensitive young man, he began to resent those who took his father's attentions away from him. What he failed to comprehend was that his father Akbar, as the Mughal Emperor, had many demands on his time, ruling over a vast empire. This tragic lack of communication led to a conflict with his father whom he held in love and esteem."

58.heading: Bravehearts.
58.title: "Jallianwala Bagh : Massacre of the Innocents"
58.author: script, Toni Patel ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
58.appears_in: p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 704 (1982, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "The day was April 13, 1919. It was the festival of Baisakhi, new year's day in the Punjab, when thousands of holidaying villagers mingled with the citizens of Amritsar to listen to their leaders in Amritsar's Jallianwala Bagh. No one even imagined that the garden would turn into a killing field. The British Brigadier-General Reginald Dyer, in a bid to teach 'a moral lesson to the Punjab,' ordered his soldiers to open fire at the unarmed crowd of men, women and children. It was a turning point in India's struggle for freedom."

59.heading: Bravehearts.
59.title: "Kalpana Chawla : the First Indian Woman in Space"
59.author: script, Margie Sastry ; illustrations, Shyam Desai ; editor, Anant Pai
59.appears_in: p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 736 (2005, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Unconventional clothes and bobbed hair were not the only indications of Kalpana's zest for life. This spirited young girl from Karnal wanted to fly! her intelligence was multi-faceted, her talents varied and her interests inspiring. The path she charted from her traditional home in Haryana to NASA's elite band of astronauts is the stuff of legends."

60.heading: Bravehearts.
60.title: "Krishnadeva Raya : the Illustrious King of Vijayanagara"
60.author: script, Subba Rao ; illustrations, G
60.appears_in: R. Naik ; editor, Anant Pai. 31 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 636 (1978, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "The king of Vijayanangara, Vira Narasimha, was very ill. He was afraid that after his death, his much loved and popular brother, Krishnadeva Raya, would seize the throne from his little son. So he asked a trusted minister to put Krishnadeva to death. The conscience-stricken minister could not perform such a heinous deed and convinced the bewildered prince to escape. Fate had already decreed that Krishnadeva Raya would one day rule the Vijayanagara empire and take it to its zenith of glory."

61.heading: Bravehearts.
61.title: "Lachit Barphukan : Legendary Commander of Assam"
61.author: script, Dhrubananda Das & Subba Rao ; illustrations, Souren Roy ; editor, Anant Pai
61.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 684 (1974, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "King Jayadhwaja Singh of Assam was worried. The Mughal general Mir Jumla had successfully attacked one of his forts. The king's only hope was Lachit, his brave brother-in-law who was also the commander of his army. Though the strain of keeping his country together killed Jayadhwaja, Lachit Barphukan led a brilliant and brave campaign against the Mughals and saved the honour of his king and his country. Lachit's story is chronicled in Assamese texts called Buranjis."

62.heading: Bravehearts.
62.title: "Lalitaditya : the Warrior Poet of Kashmir"
62.author: script, Yagya Sharma ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
62.appears_in: p. 1-30 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 690 (1985, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "From the cool valley of Kashmir to the lush coastal lands of southern India and burning desert sands of the west, Lalitaditya was master of all. This 8th-century swashbuckling hero was idolised by the poet Kalhana (12th century), in his work, Rajatarangini. An ideal king, Lalitaditya repelled invaders, eased the toil of poor peasants, and always rewarded loyal friends. But when he should have settled down to enjoy the fruits of his labour, he chose to walk away."

63.heading: Bravehearts.
63.title: "Mangal Pande : He Fired the First Shot"
63.author: script, Toni Patel ; illustrations, Souren Roy ; editor, Anant Pai
63.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 675 (1985, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "The Indian sepoys of the Native Infantry Regiment, in Barrackpore, were appalled when they heard that the cartridges they bit into before loading their guns were going to be greased with cow and pig fat. It was an insult to their religious sentiments. The murmurings of dissent rose as the news spread but the British were insensitive to the reasons behind it. And then Mangal Pandey, a sepoy from the Native Infantry, fired the shot that triggered of the First War of Indian Independence."

64.heading: Bravehearts.
64.title: "Noor Jahan : the Light of the World"
64.author: script, Laila Mahajan ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
64.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 701 (1977, 2008 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Born a poor refugee, Mehar was blessed with both spirit and talent. She could ride horseback and design fine clothes. She could lead armies to victory and yet be a doting wife. She could attend to the problems of a vast empire, and at the same time be blissfully happy making perfumes. Emperor Jahangir fell under her spell and aptly named her Noor Jahan, for she lit up the world with her love."

65.heading: Bravehearts.
65.title: "Padmini : a Tale of Love and Honour"
65.author: script, Yagya Sharma ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
65.appears_in: p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 605 (1973, 2009 printing).
notes: Begins: "Chittor is the soul of Rajasthan. Its history is the saga of Rajput valour."

Summary from back cover: "Hers was a face that made powerful monarchs lose their wits. having seen Padmini's reflection in a mirror, Sultan Ala-ud-din Khilji wanted her more than anything else in the world. But she was already the queen of brave Ratnasen, ruler of Chittor. In an unfolding drama of lust and treachery, Ratnasen's band of Rajput warriors displayed the outstanding courage for which they were rightly famous. And Padmini showed the world what love and honour mean to a woman."

66.heading: Bravehearts.
66.title: "Paurava and Alexander : Battle of the Giants"
66.author: script, Subba Rao ; illustrations, Souren Roy ; editor, Anant Pai
66.appears_in: p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 640 (1978, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "The battle between Alexander of Macedonia and King Paurava was the most difficult one the Greek invader had ever fought in his military career. Here, he was faced with an adversary whose courage and pride demanded recognition. Even though Paurava lost the battle to Alexander's brilliant strategy on the battlefield he could not be conquered by the great conqueror."

67.heading: Bravehearts.
67.title: "Prithviraj Chauhan : a Legend of Valour and Chivalry"
67.author: script, Yagya Sharma ; illustrations, P
67.appears_in: B. Kavadi ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 604 (1971, 2010 printing).
notes: Begins: "Much before the advent of the Mughals in India, Delhi was ruled by a brave king, Prithviraj Chauhan."

Summary from back cover: "Jaichand was furious! His daughter Samyogita had eloped with Prithviraj Chauhan, the warrior king of Delhi. She, like many others, was smitten by tales of his daring, his nobility and his sense of honour. Though the young couple's happiness was doomed, even in his dying hour, it was the brave Prithviraj who chose how his life should end."

68.heading: Bravehearts.
68.title: "Raja Bhoja : a Patron of the Arts and Literature"
68.author: script, Kamala Chandrakant ; illustrations, G
68.appears_in: R. Naik ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 596 (1976, 2010 printing).
notes: Begins: "Raja Bhoja was the son of King Sindhula of Dhara, in Madhya Pradesh. He was born when Sindhula was very old."

Summary from back cover: "Amidst the many wars he fought, Raja Bhoja (11th century A.D.), the ruler of Malwa, always found time to listen to the poetry of the gifted. Ballala, a poet in his court, has immortalised his patron in his work Bhoja Prabandha which is a romantic tale, written in Sanskrit, partly in verse and partly in prose. Ballala was interested not so much in history as in heroics. In his attempt to magnify Bhoja as a patron of the arts and letters, Ballala has ignored historical facts. The poets, Kalidasa and Bana, who he said adorned Bhoja's court, actually lived much before Bhoja's times."

69.heading: Bravehearts.
69.title: "Raja Raja Chola : Destined for Greatness"
69.author: script, Sita Anantharaman ; illustrations, Varnam ; editor, Anant Pai
69.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 727 (1976, 2010 printing).
notes: Begins: "About a thousand years ago, Parantaka Chola II ruled over Tanjavur in south India. He had three children, Aditya Karikalan, Arul Mozhi Verman and Kundavai."

Summary from back cover: "Arul Mozhi Varman was the younger son of the king of Thanjavur. Quiet, firm and dependable he won the heart of every person he met. However, it was his hot-headed brother who was heir to the throne. But no one could stand in the way of what destiny had in store for the young prince. By the strangest twists of fate, Arul ascended the throne as Raja Raja Chola, and proved to be one of the greatest rulers in the history of medieval India. During his 30-year-reign the Chola empire not only became a formidable maritime power but was also a hub of art and architecture."

70.heading: Bravehearts.
70.title: "Rana Kumbha : Pillar of Rajput Pride"
70.author: script, Jagjit Uppal ; illustrations, H
70.appears_in: S. Chavan & Dilip Kadam ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 676 (1979, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Victory for Mewar! His father's last words seemed to spur the young ruler on to ever greater feats. His success on the battlefield raised Rajput pride as high as the magnificent tower at Chittor, which he completed in 1448. Tirelessly subduing mighty sultans as well as sly traitors, Rana Kumbha ensured that his name was inscribed as one of the land's most worthy sons."

71.heading: Bravehearts.
71.title: "Rana Pratap : He Fought for Freedom"
71.author: script, Yagya Sharma ; illustrations, Pratap Mulick ; editor, Anant Pai
71.appears_in: 32 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 563 (1971, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Disdaining even the comfort of a bed, the valiant Rana Pratap waged a single-minded, life-long war against the might Mughal conquerors. His Rajput pride instilled a deep respect in the enemy. They realised that huge armies and sophisticated weapons are but aids, and that there can be no substitute for raw courage on the battlefield."
An earlier printing (no. 24, 1970?) credits the art to Ram Waeerkar.

72.heading: Bravehearts.
72.title: "Rana Sanga : the Valiant Warrior-King"
72.author: script, Rajendra Sanjay ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
72.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 630 (1976, 2010 printing).
notes: "Rana Sanga, the ruler of Mewar, had his eyes set on the throne of Delhi. However, the rising Mughal star Babur got rid of the Lodhi Sultan of Delhi. Thus the stage was set for the confrontation between the formidable Rana and an equally determined Babur who had just found a new home for his men: Hindustan."

73.heading: Bravehearts.
73.title: "Rani Durgavati : the Brave and Wise Queen"
73.author: script, Kamala Chandrakant ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
73.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 606 (1976, 2009 printing).
notes: Begins: "Durgavati was the daughter of the Rajput chief of Mahoba, a powerful Rajput kingdom. She rode well, was a good shot and often went out hunting with her father."

Summary from back cover: "She chose to be the wife of a brave, low-born hero rather than of a spineless high-born fool. This was indeed fortunate for the people of Garha, for they gained a queen who could befuddle even the mightiest of Mughal armies. Her intelligence and courage were unmatched. But this made the Mughal general, Asaf Khan, all the more determined to subdue her."

74.heading: Bravehearts.
74.title: "Rani of Jhansi : the Flame of Freedom"
74.author: script, Mala Singh ; illustrations, Hema Joshi ; editor, Anant Pai
74.appears_in: 32 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 539 (1974, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "She ruled over a small kingdom, but dreamt of freedom for the whole country. In the Great Revolt of 1857, Lakshmibai, the Rani of Jhansi, matched wits and force with the best of British generals. The image of the brave Rani of Jhansi charging her steed through enemy lines, her sword raised for the next thrust, is forever imprinted in Indian hearts."

75.heading: Bravehearts.
75.title: "Ranjit Singh : the Lion of Punjab"
75.author: script, Rahul Singh ; illustrations, Devender ; editor, Anant Pai
75.appears_in: p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 726 (1974, 2009 printing).
notes: Begins: "On November 13, 1780, in the small town of Budrukhan near Jind, Raj Kaur gave birth to a boy who was destined to be great."

Summary from back cover: "Even the conquering British had to tread cautiously around this one-eyed, all-seeing lion-hearted king of Punjab. Strong and outstandingly brave, Ranjit Singh defied death at every turn. Only ten years old when he first led a victorious army, he went on to become maharaja, in 1801, of all Punjab and then lands beyond."

76.heading: Bravehearts.
76.title: "Rash Behari Bose : Independent India was His Life-Long Dream"
76.author: script, Satyavrata Ghosh and Luis Fernandes
76.appears_in: p. 1-30 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 721 (1982, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "As a schoolboy and a young man he rebelled against the unfair accusation that the people of Bengal lacked courage. Determined to prove otherwise Rash Behari Bose worked to free India from British rule for 40 years. Wanted by the British police his life was one of escapades and adventure. The Indian National Army that he founded grew into a formidable force of 40,000 soldiers. He was rightly called the Father of the Indian Independence Movement in East Asia."

77.heading: Bravehearts.
77.title: "Samudra Gupta : the Lute-Playing Conqueror"
77.author: script, Kamala Chandrakant ; illustrations, Souren Roy ; editor, Anant Pai
77.appears_in: p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 648 (1984, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Can a music-loving, scholarly prince be a successful king? Will a skilled and committed warrior encourage the arts and science? Samudra Gupta proved he was a multi-faceted ruler. By bringing peace to a huge area of the warring subcontinent, this benevolent king gave his people the leisure to be creative. His court official Harishena engraved his master's achievement on the Ashoka pillar in Allahabad."

78.heading: Bravehearts.
78.title: "Shah Jahan : Emperor, Soldier, Master Builder" p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 642
78.author: [No author]
notes: Summary from back cover: "Prince Khurram was a favourite of his grandfather, Emperor Akbar, who saw in the young prince a reflection of himself. Akbar was not mistaken. Khurram proved himself to be a brave soldier, an able commander and an excellent strategist. He was certainly the natural heir to his father, Jahangir, who recognising his qualities gave him the title of Shah Jahan or Ruler of the World. But his stepmother, Noor Jahan, had other plans."

79.heading: Bravehearts.
79.title: "Shalivahana : the Man who Started an Era"
79.author: script, Jagjit Uppal ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
79.appears_in: 31 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 638 (1978, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "As a little boy Shatakarni, or Shalivahana as he was later called, watched helplessly as he and his widowed mother were thrown out of their house by his father's brothers. Sheltered by a potter the boy grew up with the prophecy of a wandering sage ringing in his ears that he would one day become king. The Sanskrit classic, Kathasaritasagar and Vikrama Charita, from which most of this story is taken, traces the path that made Shalivahana so powerful that an entire era, the Shalivahana Shaka, was named after him."

80.heading: Bravehearts.
80.title: "Sher Shah : Able Statesman, Brave Warrior"
80.author: script, Dolly Rizvi ; illustrations, H
80.appears_in: S. Chavan ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 746 (1979, 2010 printing).
notes: Begins: "Farid, who later earned the title of Sher Shah and became one of the greatest rulers of medieval India, was the son of Hasan, an Afghan estate owner of Sasaram."

81.heading: Bravehearts.
81.title: "Sultana Razia : Empress of India"
81.author: script, the editorial team ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
81.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 725 (1976, 2009 printing).
notes: Begins: "Sultana Razia was the only reigning queen who ever sat on the throne of Delhi. She was the daughter of Sultan Shamsuddin Iltutmish of the Slave Dynasty."

Summary from back cover: "Intelligent, brave, competent and just, Razia was chosen by her father, Sultan Iltutmish, to succeed him to the throne of Delhi. The people loved her and trusted her but the Amirs or nobles found it difficult to swear loyalty to a woman. Sultana Razia ruled for only three and a half years but she proved her father right by being a wise and just ruler who protected and nurtured her subjects. She led her armies and was a brave soldier. Her only enemy was the times that did not accept a woman as a leader."

82.heading: Bravehearts.
82.title: "Tales of Shivaji : the Legendary Maratha Warrior-King"
82.author: script, Subba Rao ; illustrations, Dilip Kadam ; editor, Anant Pai
82.appears_in: p. 1-30 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 597 (1982, 2010 printing).
notes: "Shivaji, famous as a warrior and patriot, was also renowned for his kindness. His behaviour managed to convert a spunky young mother, an avenging widow, and a terrified maiden into devoted friends. Not only did the powerful Maratha display humility and a constant sense of fair play, he also upheld the honour of every woman whether rich or poor, enemy or ally."

83.heading: Bravehearts.
83.title: "Tanaji : the Great Maratha Warrior"
83.author: written by Meena Talim ; illustrated by V
83.appears_in: B. Halbe. 32 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 682 (1981, 1999 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Tanaji Malasure was only a boy when he took an oath to support his friend, Shivaji, in fighting the Mughals. Along with their small band of faithful followers they became a thorn in the side of the Emperor Aurangazeb as they conquered fort after fort. Tanaji's prowess was tested when he was entrusted with the near impossible task of capturing Kondana Fort. The present story is based on Shivasmruti by G.S. Sardesai and Shivaji the Maratha: His Life and Times, by Sir H.G. Rawlinson."

84.heading: Bravehearts.
84.title: "Tipu Sultan : the Tiger of Mysore"
84.author: script, Subba Rao ; illustrations, G
84.appears_in: R. Naik ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 741 (1979, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Tipu Sultan died as he had lived, a free man. A childhood spent watching and helping in his father's campaigns had made him a shrewd general. From his father he also inherited courage and a sense of honour and, most importantly, the determination to oust the British from Indian soil. But this noble 18th-century warrior had no weapon against treachery."

85.heading: Bravehearts.
85.title: "Veer Hammir : the Noble Warrior"
85.author: script, Rajendra Sanjay ; illustrations, M
85.appears_in: N. Nangare ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 692 (1977, 2009 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Gifted with the intelligence of his mother and the courage of his father, Hammir promised to make an ideal king. But traitors grabbed his kingdom thus denying him his right to rule. Though it took him many years, Hammir tirelessly sought a peaceful way to regain his homeland, and eventually occupied the throne of his beloved Chittor without shedding a drop of blood. Kind but firm, he won the hearts of his grateful people as well as the admiration of his worst enemies."

86.heading: Bravehearts.
86.title: "Veer Savarkar : He Fought for Human Dignity and Freedom"
86.author: script, Subba Rao ; illustrations, Ram Waeerkar ; editor, Anant Pai
86.appears_in: p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 678 (1984, 2010 printing).

contents.title: "Kala Pani (Andaman and Nicobar Islands)" (fact feature) p. 16-17

notes: Summary from back cover: "The prison of Kala Pani was the destination for many Indian freedom fighters. Scores of revolutionaries were exiled to this dreaded cellular prison which was in Port Blair in the Andaman Islands. Veer Savarkar was one of them. Hounded by the police from London to Marseilles and then to India, he faced the most trying situations in his untiring effort to fight British rule. But even the despair and darkness of Kala Pani did not dim his courage. Veer Savarkar found the most unique ways to motivate his prison mates and keep their belief alive in an independent India."

87.heading: Bravehearts.
87.title: "Vikramaditya : Courage and Honour Win the Day"
87.author: script, A
87.appears_in: P. Singh ; illustrations, H.S. Chavan ; editor, Anant Pai. 31 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 568 (1972, 2010 printing).
notes: Begins: "About 1,600 years ago, a vast part of India was ruled by a great King, Samudragupta. Pataliputra was its capital. The king had two sons, Ramagupta and Chandragupta."

Summary from back cover: "Chandragupta Vikramaditya has a special place in history because he proved that the love of power is not all that is needed to create an empire. Also needed are the love of a wise woman and good, old-fashioned honour."

88.heading: Bravehearts.
88.title: "Yayati"
88.author: retold from the Mahabharata ; script, Subba Rao ; illustrations, Souren Roy
88.appears_in: 31 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 637 (1978, 1997 printing).
notes: Introduction begins: "In Hindu mythology, Yayati, the son of Nahusha, is depicted as one of the wisest and noblest rulers of the times."

Summary from back cover: "King Yayata had stopped only to quench his thirst, but the forest well presented him with a beautiful bride! All he had to do was treat her well, but womanly wiles worked their spell to destroy his happiness. It took a thousand years of indulgence to make him see the path to true contentment, and he realised that it did not lie in worldly pleasures."

90.heading: Braverman, June.
90.title: "The Last Rebel!"
90.author: Gary Friedrich, script ; Dick Ayers, pencils ; Jack Abel, inks ; June Braverman, letters
90.appears_in: 20 p. in Outlaw Kid, no. 13 (Dec. 1972) ; reprinted in Outlaw Kid, no. 30 (Oct. 1975).
notes: Villains are Jack McDaniels, and the "Last Rebel," who is introduced and dies here.
Data from Lou Mougin and Tony R. Rose via Grand Comics Database Project.

91.heading: Bravery, Captain.
91.title: "Captain Bravery, Citizen's Band's Fighting Man!, part 19"
91.author: Robert Leighton
91.appears_in: p. 21 in S9 Hobby Radio, v. 19, no. 9 (Sept. 1979).

92.heading: Bravery.
92.title: Balder the Brave.
92.author: [No author]
92.library has: no. 1-4. 1. Superhero comics. I. Marvel Comics. k. Bravery. Call no.

93.heading: Bravery.
93.title: A Berry Brave Troop
93.author: written by P
93.appears_in: Kevin Strader ; illustrated by Kenny Yamada, Charles Landholm, and Yakovetic.

94.heading: Bravery.
94.title: "Beyond Bravery"
94.author: by George J
94.appears_in: Hecht. 1 p. (text) in Real Heroes, no. 11 (Autumn 1943) I. Hecht, George J. k. Bravery. Call no.: Film 15791 r.298

95.heading: Bravery.
95.title: The Blank in the Comics strip collection includes a file of one or more daily comic strips related to this keyword or topic. Call no.: PN6726 f.B55
95.author: [No author]

96.heading: Bravery.
96.title: "The Bold Brave Moose"
96.author: by Lily K
96.appears_in: Scott. 1 p. text in Barnyard Comics, no. 17 (Apr. 1948).

97.heading: Bravery.
97.title: "Color Me Brave!"
97.author: Sam Glanzman, story and art
97.appears_in: 4 p. in Our Army at War, no. 247 (July 1972).

98.heading: Bravery.
98.title: "Do You Have A Good Dental Plan?"
98.author: Chris Browne.
notes: Summary: Hagar's recruiting a new crew, tough and willing to brave storms, shipwrecks, sea monsters, war, starvation, torture, death. Any questions?

99.heading: Bravery.
99.title: "Even Little Heroes Deserve Hugs"
99.author: Amend.
notes: Jason hugs his dad for his bravery in giving blood.

100.heading: Bravery.
100.title: Harold Teen in Only the Brave Deserve the Fair
100.author: by Kumter Bed.

101.heading: Bravery.
101.title: The Hero of Hamblett
101.author: story and pictures by Sal Murdocca.
notes: Relates in comic strip format the adventures of young Hamm of Hamblett, who, through a combination of innocence and bravery, fulfills his lifelong dream of becoming a noble knight.

102.heading: Bravery.
102.title: "How come she called me a Brave Little Soldier"
102.author: Ketcham.
notes: Key words: Hypodermics, needles, shots, doctors.

103.heading: Bravery.
103.title: "I Admire Your Bravery, but Not Your Judgment"
103.author: by Tim Rickard.
notes: Summary: The software pirate makes him walk the plank (on a leash).

104.heading: Bravery.
104.title: "I Guess He Didn't Show Up Today"
104.author: by Chris Browne.
notes: Summary: Hagar asks for a brave warrior to take the lead.

105.heading: Bravery.
105.title: "It Doesn't Take a Brave Person to Shoot Someone in the Back"
105.author: by Dean Young and John Marshall.
notes: Summary: Dagwood confronts a boy in a Punisher shirt who has just squirted him with a big squirt gun.

106.heading: Bravery.
106.title: "It Was Perfect"
106.author: by Greg Evans.
notes: Summary: Luann talks to her diary, about Aaron's new cowgirl friend Claudia, Stuart's bravery citation, and the uncomfortable meeting of Aaron and Stuart.

107.heading: Bravery.
107.title: "Only the Bravest Live!"
107.author: by Nathaniel Nitkin
107.appears_in: p. 47-48 p. text in Bulletman, no. 10 (Dec. 1942) I. Nitkin, Nathaniel. k. Bravery. Call no.: Film 15791r.179

108.heading: Bravery.
108.title: Pinocchio [videorecording]
108.author: [No author]
notes: Title on container: Walt Disney's Masterpiece Pinocchio.
Based on the story by Carlo Collodi.
Videocassette release of the 1940 animated film by Walt Disney Productions.
Directors, Ben Sharpsteen, Hamilton Luske ; story adaptation, Ted Sears, et al. ; animation, Jack Campbell, et al. ; music and lyrics by Leigh Harline, Ned Washington, Paul J. Smith.
Characters: Pinocchio, Jiminy Cricket, Geppetto, J. Worthington Foulfellow, Monstro.

Summary (from OCLC): A puppet wants to be a boy. A fairy promises boyhood to Pinocchio if he can prove he is kind, honest and loving. A wayward huckster tries to lead the puppet astray but Pinocchio decides to perform a redeeming act of bravery and kindness.

109.heading: Bravery.
109.title: "Three Chicks, One Hero!"
109.author: Art Scott
notes: Begins: "Big prize for the bravest person in town to be awarded next Sunday."

110.heading: Bravery.
110.title: "To the Brave"
110.author: by Ham Fisher.
notes: Summary: Larry leaves when he catches sight of Joe, and Knobby seems to imagine that it was his own behavior that chased him away.

111.heading: Bravery.
111.title: Walt Disney's Peter Pan Saves the Day : a Book about Bravery.
111.author: [No author]

112.heading: Bravery.
112.title: "Yo Solo lo Peino y le Lavo los Dientes!"
112.author: Fisher.
notes: Summary: Jeff's not the liontamer, a liontamer has to be tall and brave and look death in the face.

113.heading: Bravery.
113.title: "You Were Very Brave to Save Me from that Creep, Pooch"
113.author: by June Brigman and Mary Schmich.
notes: Summary: The dog is now following Brenda.

114.heading: Bravery.
114.title: You're a Brave Man, Charlie Brown
114.author: by Charles M
notes: Selected Peanuts strips from You Can Do It, Charlie Brown, v. 2.

115.heading: Braves.
115.title: The Blank in the Comics strip collection includes a file of one or more daily comic strips related to this keyword or topic. Call no.: PN6726 f.B55
115.author: [No author]

116.heading: Braves.
116.title: "Brave Little Brave"
116.author: [No author]
116.series: Tommy Hawk) 2 p. in Master Comics, no. 37
notes: Data from Bob Klein, Lou Mougin, and Jim Vadeboncoeur via The Grand Comics Database Project.

117.heading: Braves.
117.title: The Three Stooges : Chief Crazy-Nose and his unbrave braves don war paint to become Fine Feathered Fugitives.
117.author: [No author]

118.heading: Braves.
118.title: "The Young Brave" 2 p. text in Captain Flash, v. 1, no. 1
118.author: [No author]

119.heading: "The Bravest of Brides" p. 24-27 in Real Heroes, no. 2 (Dec.
119.author: [No author]
notes: "The story of Mary Mugford of Marblehead, who, singlehanded, rescued her husband from an enemy man-o-'war."

120.title: "The Bravest Person in This Family"
120.author: Russell Myers.
notes: Summary: Beanz is proud that he's mastered the beginner's slope, and in the background Perky and Yoyo are flying off a ski jump with one ski between them.

124.title: Bravestarr in 3-D. No. 1
124.author: story, John Stephenson ; art, Adrian Moro ; letters, Susan Kronz; 3-D process, Bob and Nancy Fritsch.
notes: Title from cover. 1. Western comic books, strips, etc. I. Stephenson, John. II. Moro, Adrian. Call no.: PN6728.5.B55B7 1987

125.title: Braveu, Heinz!
125.author: Eddie de Jong en Rene Windig.
notes: Eerder verschenen van 7 april 1999 tot 29 april 2000 in dagstroken.
Oorspr. titel: Niet ziet jij wat, zie zie ik ik!

126.heading: Bravo, Colonel.
126.title: Wonder Woman : The Encyclopedia of Comic Book Heroes, v. 2
126.author: Michael Fleisher

127.heading: Bravo, Edgar.
127.title: Mi Hermano
127.author: libreto: Socorro Valdez, Peter Rabinowitz, Edgar Bravo, Nelly Delouya, Esther Ricardo ; fotografía, Richard Lewis.

Center for Disease Control. V. United States. Office of Disease Prevention and Health Promotion. Call no.: RA644.A25.V3 1990

128.title: My Brother

131.heading: Bravo, Emile, 1964- --Miscellanea.
131.title: Dictionnaire Encyclopédique de Héros et Auteurs de BD
131.author: Henri Filippini

132.heading: Bravo, Emile, 1964- --Miscellanea.
132.title: Contributor note and bibliography in Comix 2000
132.author: [No author]

133.heading: Bravo, Fran.
133.title: De la Historieta y su Uso, 1873-2000
133.author: Jesús Cuadrado
133.series: Atlas Español de la Cultura Popular ; v. 1

134.heading: Bravo, Jesse--Miscellanea.
134.title: Adventure Heroes, Legendary Characters from Odysseus to James Bond
134.author: Jeff Rovin

135.title: De la Historieta y su Uso, 1873-2000
135.author: Jesús Cuadrado
135.series: Atlas Español de la Cultura Popular ; v. 1

139.heading: Bravo C., Rogelio.
139.title: Historia de un Recluta de 1813
139.author: Erckman-Chatrian ; adaptacion, H

contents.title: Historia de un Recluta de 1813, by Erckman-Chatrian. La Alucinacion de Stanley Fleming, by A. Bierce. 1. Napoleon I, Emperor of the French, 1769-1821

notes: Comic books, strips, etc. 2. War comics. 3. Mexican comics. I. Comte, H. II. Bravo C., Rogelio. III. Erckmann-Chatrian. IV. Bierce, Ambrose, 1842-1914? V. La Alucinacion de Stanley Fleming. VI. Series. Call no.: PN6790.M44N64no.318
